title: 106_hr4208
content: The Act may be cited as the "Recruiting, Retention, and Reservist Promotion Act of 2000" and includes provisions for per diem allowance for lengthy or numerous deployments. The "Recruiting, Retention, and Reservist Promotion Act of 2000" includes provisions for expedited implementation of high-deployment per diem allowance eligibility and the inclusion of the Coast Guard in section 435 of title 37, United States Code. The "Recruiting, Retention, and Reservist Promotion Act of 2000" amends section 435 of title 37, United States Code to include the Coast Guard. Additionally, section 991 of title 10, United States Code is amended to clarify military department concerns. A study on eligibility thresholds will be conducted by the Secretary of Defense in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, will conduct a study on the high-deployment per diem allowance for members of the Armed Forces. The study will assess the allowance's impact on morale, retention, and recruitment rates, as well as explore the feasibility of establishing reduced eligibility thresholds for National Guard and Reserve members on active duty for over 30 days. A report must be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Defense will submit a report to Congress with recommendations on adjusting eligibility thresholds and per diem rates for high-deployment allowances. If deemed necessary, the Secretary may lower the deployment threshold from 251 days to a more suitable number and must inform Congress of any changes made. SEC. 3. STUDY OF TAX CREDITS AND SMALL BUSINESS LOAN CHANGES TO ASSIST BUSINESSES EMPLOYING GUARD AND RESERVE MEMBERS. The Comptroller General will conduct a study to determine if National Guard and Reserve members are overrepresented in businesses, the appropriate Federal tax benefit for businesses employing them, and potential changes to small business loan programs to help cover costs related to employing these members. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment, containing legislative proposals for a recommended tax benefit and modifications to the small business loan program to support businesses employing National Guard and Reserve members. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment, containing legislative proposals for a recommended tax benefit and modifications to the small business loan program to support businesses employing National Guard and Reserve members. Additionally, there will be a report on the expansion of Junior ROTC and similar military programs for young people. Congress finds that the Junior Reserve Officers' Training Corps, Civil Air Patrol, Naval Sea Cadet Corps, and Young Marines provide significant benefits for the Armed Forces and there is interest in expanding these programs. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within 180 days assessing the feasibility and desirability of expanding these programs. The Secretary may expand programs like Junior Reserve Officers' Training Corps, Civil Air Patrol, Naval Sea Cadet Corps, and Young Marines through increased units, participants, or funding as deemed appropriate.
